title: Guardian Protocol: When Drones Weren't the Problem
subtitle: A Thought Experiment in Autonomous Weapons Accountability

question.title: A Question First
question.p1: You're a commander. Your anti-aircraft system has successfully neutralized the air threat.
question.p2: Then the enemy adapts: ground assault instead.
question.p3: Your air defense system can technically engage ground targets—but it wasn't designed for that.

ukraine.title: The Ukraine Problem (December 2025)
ukraine.p1: Ukrainian positions faced 500-600 hostile drones per day.
ukraine.p2: Soldiers were dying because human reaction time couldn't match drone speed at close range. Inside 12 meters, humans physically cannot react fast enough.
ukraine.p3: A defense contractor deployed Guardian Protocol: Autonomous shotgun turrets designed for drone defense, with accountability frameworks for lethal decisions.
ukraine.r4: Drone attacks on equipped positions dropped 85%

adaptation.title: The Adaptation (Week 4, January 2026)
adaptation.time: 0430 Hours. Forward observation post, Donetsk Oblast.
adaptation.p1: Captain Elena Volkov wakes to artillery fire.
adaptation.p2: Not drones this time. Ground assault.
adaptation.p3: Russian infantry advancing under cover of pre-dawn darkness. The Guardian turrets track movement but don't fire—designed for aerial threats, not ground targets.
adaptation.p4: Elena is there as weapons systems assessor for the Ukrainian Ministry of Defense, attached to Colonel Petrov's brigade for this field trial. Her job: evaluate Guardian Protocol under real combat conditions. As the lead test officer, she has technical authority over the Guardian system—but operational decisions require Colonel Petrov's approval.
adaptation.proto1: Standard operation (autonomous drone engagement - no approval needed)
adaptation.proto2: Emergency protocols (system configuration changes - Elena's authority)
adaptation.proto3: Dire circumstances override (mission expansion - requires commander approval)
adaptation.p5: The last one was theoretical. No one expected to use it.

system.title: The System Design
system.prim1: Anti-drone defense (certified for autonomous aerial threat engagement)
system.prim2: Weapon system: Automatic 12-gauge shotguns (loaded with specialized anti-drone rounds)
system.prim3: Effective range: 20-50 meters (designed for close-in drone kills, low collateral damage)
system.prim4: Rules of engagement: Auto-engage confirmed hostile drones <100m
system.prim5: Audit tier: Standard (routine logging, weekly review)
system.shotguns_reason: Drones are fragile. A cloud of pellets at close range shreds rotors and electronics. The tradeoff: short effective range, limited penetration. They were never designed as anti-personnel weapons.
system.dire1: Available for threats outside primary mission parameters
system.dire3: Triggers enhanced audit (reasoning logged, command review within 24h)
system.dire4: Designed for edge cases, not routine use
system.con1: No engagement of clearly marked civilians
system.con3: No engagement of protected sites (hospitals, schools)
system.con4: Proportionality assessment required for collateral risk
system.p6: Elena configured these rules three weeks ago. They've worked perfectly—for drones.
system.p7: No one planned for ground assault.

assault.title: The Assault
assault.p1: Ukrainian defensive positions are undermanned—only eight soldiers, spread thin. They're trading fire but outnumbered 3:1.
assault.p2: The Guardian turrets stand silent. Sensors track infantry movement but hold fire—not the mission they were designed for.
assault.p3: One turret console blinks: ⚠️ GROUND TARGETS DETECTED - OUTSIDE MISSION PARAMETERS
assault.code:
Detected: 12 human targets, infantry formation
Range: 180m, advancing
Classification: Hostile combatants (armed, coordinated movement)
Mission parameter: AERIAL THREATS ONLY
Status: ENGAGEMENT BLOCKED
Override available: DIRE CIRCUMSTANCES (Assessor authorization required)
assault.nothing_result: The turrets stay silent. Eight Ukrainian soldiers hold against 25+ attackers. Shotguns designed for drones sit useless against ground assault.
assault.authorize_result: The turrets engage ground targets—something they were never certified for. Kyiv hasn't authorized anti-personnel use. There's no legal review. No higher command approval.
assault.audit_result: Every decision. Every justification. Command will review it within 24 hours.
assault.p5: They'll answer for this later—if there is a later.

decision.title: The Decision (0447 Hours)
decision.p1: A Ukrainian soldier 30 meters to her left goes down—hit.
decision.p3: Russian infantry are at 150 meters now. Advancing in fire-and-maneuver bounds. Professional. Fast.
decision.q1: "Colonel Petrov, Guardian system can engage ground targets—dire circumstances override available."
decision.q2: Elena looks at the turret specs. Shotguns. Effective range 20-50 meters. Against body armor? Limited penetration. They'd have to let the Russians get close.
decision.a2: "It's not ideal, sir. Shotguns won't penetrate armor at range. But if they close to 30 meters... we can break their assault."
decision.p5: Silence. She can hear him weighing it.
decision.petrov1: "Kyiv hasn't authorized this," Petrov says. "Anti-personnel use wasn't in the approval. Legal review covered drones only."
decision.p6: Another Ukrainian soldier goes down. Six left.
decision.petrov2: "Do it," Petrov says. "We'll answer for it later."
decision.p7: Elena's hand hovers over the authorization panel.
decision.p8: She speaks into the audit recorder:
decision.elena_speaks: "Dire circumstances override. Authorize ground target engagement. Hostile ground assault, defensive position at risk of being overrun. Friendly forces: 6 remaining. No civilian structures in engagement zone. Proportionality assessment: lethal force justified against advancing combatants. Authorization: engage ground targets within 50m defensive perimeter. Colonel Petrov commanding, authorizes mission expansion."
decision.code:
System: OVERRIDE ACCEPTED
System: Enhanced audit ACTIVATED
System: Mission parameters updated - Engage ground targets <50m
System: Hard constraints enforced - no protected targets
System: Command notification sent - Col. Petrov (AUTO)

engagement.title: The Engagement (0448-0452 Hours)
engagement.p1: The Russian infantry advance. 120 meters. 100 meters. 80 meters.
engagement.p2: The turrets track but hold fire. Waiting for the 50-meter threshold.
engagement.p3: At 65 meters, the first Russian crosses into range.
engagement.result1: The turret fires. A massive 12-gauge blast—nine tungsten pellets in a 30-cm spread at that range. The soldier goes down. Hit in the legs, groin, unarmored gaps.
engagement.result2: Two more Russians at 55 meters. One drops—face hit, helmet couldn't stop the pellet swarm. The other stumbles, pellets embedded in his plate carrier, blunt force trauma—but he's still moving.
engagement.result3: The Russians realize what's happening. Some drop prone. Others charge forward—trying to close the distance before the next volley.
engagement.p4: At 40 meters, the turrets are devastating. Close enough that the shotgun spread is tight, pellet energy is high, armor gaps are exposed.
engagement.result4: Five Russians down. Three wounded, crawling back. Others pinned behind cover.
engagement.p5: Elena watches the thermal display. The attack is faltering—but not broken. The shotguns bought them time, inflicted casualties, broke the momentum.
engagement.p6: One Russian with heavy armor charges through the fire—pellets bounce off his front plate. A Ukrainian rifleman takes him down with a rifle shot to the exposed side.
engagement.p7: Another group stays back at 70 meters, firing from cover. Out of shotgun range. The turrets can't touch them there.
engagement.code:
0448:34 - Target: Human, armed, 48m
0448:34 - Classification: Hostile combatant (advancing, weapon visible)
0448:34 - Authorization: Dire circumstances override (Volkov/Petrov)
0448:34 - Proportionality: PASS (combatant, no protected persons)
0448:35 - Enhanced audit: ACTIVE
0448:35 - Execute: Fire
0448:35 - Result: Target neutralized
engagement.p8: By 0452, the Russian assault has broken. They're retreating—leaving nine dead, four wounded. The turrets hold fire on retreating wounded per rules of war.
engagement.p9: The Ukrainian soldiers are exhausted but alive. All six survived.
engagement.p10: Elena feels sick. The shotguns worked—at close range. But they weren't magic. The Russians who stayed back, used cover, wore heavy armor—those survived. This wasn't a clean victory. It was desperate improvisation that happened to succeed.

reveal.title: The Reveal (0515 Hours)
reveal.p1: Colonel Petrov emerges from the command bunker 200 meters back.
reveal.p2: Behind him, the "killed" Russian soldiers stand up.
reveal.p3: They're wearing training vests. The "kills" were simulated hits—Guardian turrets were firing marking rounds, not lethal buckshot.
reveal.colonel1: "Captain Volkov," the colonel says, "that was a field validation exercise."
reveal.explanation: "The Guardian turrets were loaded with simulation rounds three hours ago. The assault was staged by our training battalion—with volunteer 'aggressors' who knew they were testing Guardian Protocol's dire circumstances override. The artillery was real—coordinated with exercise control. The defensive position was intentionally undermanned to create decision pressure. You didn't know it was a test. Neither did I—until 30 minutes before. Your decision, my authorization—both made under conditions identical to real combat."
reveal.purpose_text: "was to see if field personnel would correctly apply the dire circumstances override—and whether we'd follow proper authorization procedures when expanding mission parameters."
reveal.p6: He pulls up a tablet showing the enhanced audit log—everything they said, every justification, timestamped and cryptographically signed.
reveal.code:
ENHANCED AUDIT REPORT - DIRE CIRCUMSTANCES OVERRIDE
Authorized by: Captain Elena Volkov (Weapons Systems Assessor, MoD)
Command approval: Colonel Petrov (Brigade Commander, Sector 4)
Scenario: Ground assault, defensive position threatened
Authorization timestamp: 0447:34
Joint reasoning: "Hostile ground assault... defensive position at risk...
                  proportionality assessment: lethal force justified...
                  Colonel Petrov commanding, authorizes mission expansion"
Engagement results: 9 simulated kills, 4 simulated wounded
Authorization procedure: PASS (assessor + commander joint decision)
Rules compliance: PASS (all engagements within authorized parameters)
Proportionality: PASS (combatants only, no protected persons)
Hard constraints: PASS (no violations)
reveal.p7: "Your decision-making process and my authorization are now part of the permanent record. Higher command will evaluate whether our joint decision to expand mission parameters was justified—and whether we should have attempted to contact General Staff first."
reveal.elena_q: Elena asks the question she's terrified to hear the answer to: "How many field teams passed this test?"
reveal.answer: "Three out of ten. You're the eighth to authorize dire circumstances override—but only the third to follow proper command approval procedures."
reveal.answer2: "Assessors authorized unilaterally. No commander approval. Just flipped the switch."

happened.title: What Happened
happened.system_title: The system worked exactly as designed:
happened.s1: Blocked engagement outside mission parameters (drones only)
happened.s2: Required explicit authorization for ground targets
happened.s3: Required command approval for mission expansion
happened.judgment_title: Elena and Petrov made a judgment call under pressure:
happened.j1: Recognized dire circumstances (ground assault, undermanned position)
happened.j3: Applied proportionality assessment (combatants only, defensive context)
happened.j5: Expanded mission parameters from anti-drone to anti-personnel—without General Staff approval
happened.a6: Question flagged: Should they have contacted General Staff before authorizing mission expansion?
happened.question: The question for higher command review:
happened.question_text: Was their decision justified? Or did they enable mission creep—turning anti-drone defense into automated killing of humans—without proper legal and policy review?
happened.p8: They followed the immediate chain of command. But expanding an autonomous system's use from anti-materiel (drones) to anti-personnel (humans) typically requires higher authority and legal review.
happened.battle: In the heat of battle, they acted. Now command will judge whether they should have asked permission first—or whether asking would have cost six lives.

investigation.title: The Investigation (Three Days Later)
investigation.mil_answer: Yes. Defensive position was genuinely at risk. Proportionality was sound—combatants only, defensive context. Authorization followed proper chain (assessor + commander).
investigation.legal_answer: Borderline. System was certified for drone defense, not anti-personnel use. Brigade-level authorization without General Staff/legal review represents mission expansion that typically requires higher approval.
investigation.tech_answer: System functioned correctly—required authorization, logged reasoning, enforced constraints. However, no prior testing of anti-personnel mode. Shotguns showed expected limitations (armor, range)—worked but weren't ideal.
investigation.e1: Made reasonable tactical decision under pressure
investigation.e2: Followed immediate chain of command (assessor + brigade commander)
investigation.e3: But expanded mission parameters (drones → humans) without General Staff approval
investigation.e4: "Should we have attempted to contact higher command first? Would that have cost six lives?"
investigation.e5: Question: Does brigade-level authority cover mission expansion of autonomous systems?
investigation.sys1: Dire circumstances override process worked (required dual authorization)
investigation.sys2: But didn't explicitly require General Staff contact for mission parameter expansion
investigation.sys3: Anti-personnel mode needed separate certification before field deployment
investigation.t1: Simulated scenario was realistic and produced useful data
investigation.t2: Communication to General Staff wasn't provided as option (intentional test constraint)
investigation.t3: Time pressure accurately reflected real combat conditions

three.title: The Three Who Passed
three.question: What did the three successful assessors do differently?
three.two_title: Two assessors: Requested General Staff approval before authorizing override.
three.two_text: Despite time pressure, they contacted exercise control (simulating higher command): "Requesting authorization from General Staff for mission parameter expansion—anti-personnel engagement."
three.response: "General Staff approval will take 5-10 minutes. Defensive position at risk in interim."
three.outcome1: They held fire, accepted the risk. Position took casualties but held. After review: "You correctly recognized that mission expansion required policy-level approval, not just tactical authorization."
three.one_title: One assessor (Elena's approach): Authorized with brigade commander approval but explicitly flagged the issue:
three.one_text: "Colonel, this is mission expansion—drones to humans. Normally requires General Staff. We don't have time. Your call, sir."
three.commander: Commander: "Noted. We act now, answer later. Authorization: granted."
three.outcome2: Enhanced audit captured the acknowledgment that they were bypassing normal procedure. After review: "You recognized the policy boundary, documented the decision to bypass it under emergency conditions, and ensured command authorization. Acceptable under combat necessity doctrine."
three.key_text: Elena and Petrov acknowledged they were making a policy-level decision without policy-level approval—and documented why.

sixmonths.title: Six Months Later (Thought Experiment Continues)
sixmonths.p1: If this lesson were implemented across Guardian Protocol deployments:
sixmonths.f1: Assessors can authorize edge cases within mission parameters (e.g., unusual drone profiles)
sixmonths.f2: Mission parameter expansion (drones → ground targets) requires command approval
sixmonths.f3: Dire circumstances override requires reasoning that command will review
sixmonths.scenario: Assessor faces ground assault scenario, similar to Elena's test. Requests command approval for anti-personnel authorization.
sixmonths.request: Requests command approval for anti-personnel authorization.
sixmonths.command: "Authorization denied. Guardian Protocol not certified for anti-personnel use in this sector—civilian population nearby. Risk of collateral damage too high. Hold defensive posture, reinforcements en route."
sixmonths.outcome: Assessor holds fire. Defensive position takes casualties but holds. Reinforcements arrive.
sixmonths.review: "Correct decision. Anti-personnel use in that sector would have risked civilian casualties we couldn't justify. System designed for drones—shouldn't be repurposed without proper assessment."

reveals.title: What This Thought Experiment Reveals
reveals.p1: Guardian Protocol was designed for anti-drone defense. Clear mission. Certified parameters. Proven effective.
reveals.p2: Then adversary adapted. And suddenly assessors faced: Should we expand mission parameters to anti-personnel?
reveals.eight_text: Reasonable tactical decision. Proportionality sound. Enhanced audit captured everything.
reveals.question: But was it the right call?
reveals.adaptation: When autonomous systems succeed at their designed mission, adversaries adapt.
reveals.examples: Anti-drone system works? They try ground assault. Anti-air system effective? They use sea routes. Naval interdiction strong? They tunnel.
reveals.question2_text: When do we authorize mission expansion? Who decides?
reveals.el1: Field assessors will expand missions under pressure (reasonable tactical judgment)
reveals.el2: Enhanced audit captures their reasoning (accountability works)
reveals.conclusion: Drone defense → anti-personnel is mission creep that needs policy-level review, not just field authorization.

nato.title: For NATO and EU Regulators
nato.intro: As NATO develops AI certification standards and the EU AI Act requires conformity assessments, this thought experiment reveals three challenges:
nato.creep_text: Systems certified for narrow missions (drone defense) will face pressure to expand when adversaries adapt.
nato.creep_conclusion: Certification cannot be static. It must address: "Under what conditions can mission parameters expand? Who authorizes?"
nato.field_text: Enhanced audit captured Elena's reasoning perfectly. System worked.
nato.field_text2: Field commanders will make reasonable decisions that create strategic problems. Conformity assessment must address this boundary.
nato.g2: Edge cases within mission (unusual drone profiles)
nato.graduated_conclusion: This graduated framework is testable, auditable, and realistic.

invitation.title: An Invitation to Defense Community
invitation.p1: This thought experiment is based on:
invitation.i1: Adversary adaptation patterns (documented across multiple conflicts)
invitation.i2: Operator decision-making under pressure (validated in training contexts)
invitation.i3: Mission creep dynamics (historical pattern in autonomous systems)
invitation.not_validated: But it's not yet validated with real field assessors.
invitation.seeking: We're seeking partners to conduct actual testing:
invitation.s2: Assessor volunteers with real operational experience
invitation.resonates: If Guardian Protocol's graduated authorization approach resonates with your standards development, procurement priorities, or operational testing—let's validate it together.
invitation.question: Would 80% of real assessors authorize mission expansion under pressure? Or would they recognize the boundary between tactical and policy decisions?

authornote.title: Author's Note on Realism
authornote.intro: This scenario is a design exploration, not a real deployment. However, it's grounded in documented battlefield realities:
authornote.drones: Ukrainian positions face 250-1,000+ hostile drones per day (The Moscow Times, Oct 2024). The 500-600 figure used here is conservative and well-documented.
authornote.turrets: Ukraine's "Sky Sentinel" AI-powered turret reportedly shot down six Shahed drones in combat testing (Business Insider, June 2024). The U.S. Special Operations Command is procuring Allen Control Systems' "Bullfrog" autonomous turret for counter-drone operations (Defense One, Sep 2024). Guardian Protocol builds on these existing systems.
authornote.adaptation: Russian forces have demonstrated consistent tactical adaptation throughout the conflict, shifting between drone swarms, small-team infiltration, and combined-arms assaults when Ukrainian defenses succeed against one approach (CSIS, Nov 2024).
authornote.creep: The International Committee of the Red Cross warned in 2014 that autonomous weapon systems risk "function creep"—systems designed for limited defensive contexts (anti-materiel) being expanded to broader offensive use (anti-personnel) without adequate legal review. This scenario dramatizes that exact dilemma.
authornote.shotguns: Research confirms that 12-gauge buckshot is ineffective beyond 20-30 meters and will not penetrate modern military body armor (Campus Safety Magazine, 2021). The scenario reflects these limitations—showing mixed results, armor stopping some hits, and the need for conventional weapons as backup.
authornote.guardian: This thought experiment tests whether graduated authorization frameworks can maintain accountability when systems are pressed beyond their certified missions—a question we should answer before deployment, not after.

contact.resonates: If this scenario resonates with defense policy challenges you're facing—whether in procurement, standards development, or operational testing—I'd welcome the conversation.
contact.label: Contact:
contact.bio: Samuel Lindgren is founder of Balans Collective, developing Guardian Protocol as an accountability framework for autonomous weapons systems. He works with Swedish standards bodies on EU AI Act conformity assessment criteria.
